title: Kalista is a mistake and should have never been released
body: Riot you said it with {{champion:8}} can't you admit it with {{champion:429}} as well?

Personally, I would say it not *only* her passive.
Her passive in a vacuum isn't as big an issue as people make it out to be. But in addition to it she can. . .
Do 20% max health magic damage (flat base value).
Out-smite jungle Nunu with only a small bit of wind-up.
Maintain a near perma-slow.
Engage/save an ally with an ult that gets abused by trolls in Yolo Queue.
Pump out multiple roaming wards.
Ignore slows.
And continue to dash even when silenced.


Everything together just makes for a very frustrating experience. And historically, ban rates depict frustration more than power at all elo's (more so at lower levels). She's not OP, and I don't think anyone (reasonable) is actually arguing that anymore. But she's very difficult to play against, even with a well organized team. And that's what makes her such a problem.

Spellvamp.

Prior to Vlad, spellvamp could be a lot stronger than what it currently is.  But with his kit, he absolutely breaks spellvamp.  His E alone does that much.  Each stack of empower it gives him increases the effectiveness of his self heal, health regen and spellvamp.  Each stack increases them by 4 / 5 / 6 / 7 / 8% and can stack up to four times multiplicative.  This lets him increase the effectiveness of spellvamp by up to 36% and that is without {{item:3065}}.  It also increases the effectiveness of his self heal from his Q.  Add this on top of a passive that makes him naturally tanky by simply building AP and a kit that requires spellvamp and you've got a ludicrous champion on your hands.  And this is Vlad in his current form, after being hard nerfed and he can still be a monster late game.

To be fair, I'd say that it's actually a testament to the genius of Yasuo's design.  
Sub-par unless played very well, but very rewarding when he is played very well.  He's not broken freelo, but he's not unviable, either.  He has a design that some people really enjoy, and it creates a following of players that want to master him to do well with him.  
I'd say that's an excellent champion design...he was just out of control on release.  (Before all the nerfs/balance changes.)

**Kalista, however, is an inherently broken design.  I definitely agree there.**

Her passive counters melees with the infinite kiting...but it also counters ranged champions by giving her incredible skillshot-dodging.  What? 
"Point and click CC" isn't even a "weakness" of hers...It's just the only remaining thing she isn't incredibly strong against. 
 
For example:  Targeted CC is only said to be her weakness because she is practically immune to skillshots - **not because Targeted CC actually hurts her any more than other champions.**  
It's just equally effective on her as it is on everyone else.  
So it's not a weakness at all.  It's just the one thing she's not near-invincible to.

To really drive that point home:
Almost everyone gets locked down by point-and-click CC (except maybe Irelia, Olaf...) but unlike most champions, Kalista has some of the best chances of hopping off to safety once that CC wears off.  And movement speed slow-stacking won't meaningfully reduce the distance of her hops either.  
*That means she's even strong against her one "weakness."*  Finally catch her out, then watch her hop away to safety.

I don't know why either of them even exists.

The main MASSIVE difference between {{champion:157}} and {{champion:429}} is that Yasuo is melee. He actually needs to go in and risk being focussed to get his reward. Kalista really doesn't. She's a Yasuo that's ranged and that's bad design from the get go. She doesn't really need to put herself at risk of being focused because of her high kite and range. Her high kiting ability already puts her in a safe spot.
Whereas Yasuo, if he fucks a little bit with wall placement or positioning around minions and targets, he'll get CCed and stunned pretty easily and won't be able to Sweeping Blade his way out of there, if both targets are unavailable, the way Kalista hops out of dire situations.

You also forget that Windwall is on a pretty high cooldown until late game because people don't typical max it over Sweeping Blade after maxing Steel Tempest. 
Now I'm not saying a **godly** Yasuo is easy to play against but it's exactly what you need to do with him to excel compared to Kalista, where anyone who practices 10 or more games can escape any situation with her hop and even easier with her ultimate, that is essentially a guaranteed gap closer for your team's heavy CC, heavy tank.

you are in defensive mode, but champions that have Kalista level kite should not have Kalista level teamfight. its ridiculous, giving an adc the tools to both destroy tanks and bruisers without even caring, and having no real cost to escape. pair that with an aoe knockup, percent health damage, and an ability that ends up being a great execute paired with a slow in case you missed the kill, and you end up with what many believe to be a retarded champion. 

You bring Yasuo up, but Yasuo wasn't designed to completely counter a class of champion, he was designed to be able to go toe to toe with them, being melee is already a disadvantage to being ranged, and quite a big one at that, so a ranged designed to counter melee, which they already do, is ridiculous.
The only other champion who has Kalista level kiting has better team fight and has been around a hell of a lot longer.

If you're referring to ashe, I'll have to disagree with you, kalista is much better at kiting, and has a comparable teamfight, thats slightly better if you're playing well.

ez, graves, corki? worse teamfight and kite.
sivir? Jinx? draven? Miss fortune? they all lack the kite possibility.

there is no other adc in the game with as much kite and teamfight potential as kalista. 
no other adc has a safe a laning phase paired with as much power mid to late game. there is no point where kalista is weak, and she can be intensly strong. 
she has a hard advantage against melee while still having a completely unfair advantage against ranged characters. the only fair part of kalista is that you need more than two neurons to play her, but it doesn't make up for the fact that she has so many tools to turn fights into her favor that its almost not worth fighting her.

Kalista is fun, playing against her is a mini game. But whenever you can't just run at something and make it die, it makes little babies sad.

>But whenever you can't just run at something and make it die, it makes little babies sad.

Well, if you're playing a melee against a ranged champion, generally you have to close on them if you want to interact with them. That's just kind of how it works. I mean, what do you expect melees to do? Never interact with her? But that's often a bruiser's job--to dive the carry. Someone magically kill her *without* closing on her? 

How is it a "minigame" to play someone like udyr against kalista? One she gets one or two attack speed items, she's basically completely immune to his kit unless someone else CC's her for a LONG time. 

Riot has stated over and over again that they don't like hard counters. Counterplay should happen in game, not in the champ select screen. I don't think Kalista is grossly overpowered; her problem is that her kit design boxes out a lot of champions.

It's a simple lesson: don't just run at Kalista. If she can't just ram her head into an Udyr and kill him every time he enters her field of vision, why does he HAVE TO be able to do that to her?

The minigame is in manipulating positioning and coordinating with teammates so she can't escape easily. It's like chess - you don't just align your rook with a king and deliver checkmate, you manipulate your pieces and the enemy's available moves to create a scenario that favors you.

Yes because every match of League is a premade with close friends who you know the weaknesses and strengths of.
Casual non-rank soloQ League is very dissimilar to chess. You don't know all the capabilities and skills, or what the pieces are thinking, you're but one piece out of 5, the other 4 you can't control. 

That given, 5v5 maybe, if you're really that well co-ordinated and you tailor your champions to deal effectively against a Kalista.

Thing is, every champion is countered by crowd control.  Got a Riven running toward you?  Stun her.  Udyr's trying to run away?  Slow him down.  Kalista's kiting you?  Snare her.  My basic understanding of Kalista's strengths and weaknesses looks something like this:

Pros: Incredible kiting, high burst at the end of trades, strong team-fighting and AOE damage, vision via Sentinels, scales well with flat AD and attack speed, %HP nuke on a short cooldown.

Cons: Back-loaded damage (need extended trades to win), cannot cancel AA, doesn't scale well with crit, feels clunky early game from lack of attack speed, less effective if binded ally is disconnected or not near you.  Lack of built in steroids.

Also, how is her last hitting very difficult?  Her E resets (and refunds some mana too) if you kill at least one target so I can't imagine its incredibly difficult.

Trust me even with refund her E uses ALOT of mana so you can't use that for last hitting for long

Also she can save her Support from dying by ulting. Teamfighting with her is very safe.

Sivir is also good at teamfighting because of AoE. Jinx because of AoE and range. Tristana because of resetting leap. Graves because of AoE.

But she has good mobility.
